title: 105_hr1749
content: The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title. Improvements in ERISA enforcement with respect to managed care group health plans are outlined in the act. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" introduces additional remedies for violations of plan terms related to managed care group health plans under ERISA. These remedies address failures to provide benefits in accordance with plan terms due to clinically inappropriate decisions resulting from cost containment techniques. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" holds defendants liable for restricting medical care discretion, leading to damages for participants or beneficiaries. Managed care plans must provide benefits in accordance with plan terms, or face liability for actual and punitive damages. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" holds specified defendants liable for failing to provide benefits under managed care plans through participating providers or financial incentives. The term 'specified defendant' includes the plan sponsor or health insurance issuer offering coverage. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" holds specified defendants liable for failure to provide benefits through participating providers. Remedies under this paragraph are additional to those provided under the Act. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" holds defendants liable for failure to provide benefits through participating providers. Amendments to Section 502 of the Act provide indemnification for liability of providers bound by plan restrictions on medical communications. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" ensures full indemnification for participating providers in managed care plans for any liability resulting from plan restrictions on medical communications. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" guarantees participating providers in managed care plans full protection from liability related to restrictions on medical communications, including written or oral statements regarding patient health care needs and treatment under group health plans or insurance coverage. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" ensures that providers are protected from liability for communications related to patient care, including discussions on tests, treatments, risks, benefits, and differences among healthcare providers and institutions. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" focuses on comparing medical care institutions in terms of quality, outcomes, decision-making processes for authorizing or denying benefits, and financial incentives provided by managed care group health plans or health insurance issuers. The "Managed Care Plan Accountability Act of 1997" focuses on comparing medical care institutions based on quality, outcomes, decision-making processes, and financial incentives provided by managed care group health plans or health insurance issuers. Disincentives to medical care providers based on service utilization are regulated under specific provisions. SEC. 3. EXCISE TAX FOR COST-DRIVEN VIOLATIONS OF PLAN TERMS. This section introduces a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code regarding failure to provide health benefits due to improper cost-driven delivery policy decisions. In group health coverage, failure to provide benefits due to inappropriate cost containment techniques or medical care delivery policies violates this chapter. The section applies to group health coverage provided under managed care, defined as coverage under a group health plan or health insurance coverage. Managed care involves coverage through participating providers or financial incentives for participants to use participating providers. The section defines providers as group health plans or health insurance issuers for coverage under managed care. It also includes definitions for group health plan, health insurance coverage, and health insurance issuer as per section 9805. Subtitle K in the Code now covers group health plan requirements, including portability, access, renewability, and addressing failures to provide health benefits due to cost-driven policy decisions. The amendments made by this Act will be effective for plan years starting on or after January 1, 1998.
